div.dateline: Boston— Steamer Acadia. Tuesday 1. September 1840. At Sea
div.p: Went into Boston in the Carriage, with my Son, his wife and Son Charles— Stop’d at Dr Frothingham’s— Then Mrs Charles went with me to Chaffin’s shop, and chose for me two black Stocks, according to order. Then at Charles’s Office alone— Found Mr Curtis there— Degrand came in and gave me some Newspapers— Snarl between Henry Clay and Andrew Jackson— Queer correspondence between Daniel Webster and Nicholas Biddle; about National and State Bankruptcy, and the examples of France and England— I had received a note from Lieutenant Sturges of the Revenue Cutter, offering to take me in his barge from India wharf to the Steamer— Degrand promised me to return my thanks to Lieutenant Sturges, and to make my apology for not accepting his offer— Return with Charles to Dr Frothingham’s.— Took leave of him, Mrs Frothingham, their son Thomas, Harriet Welsh and Mrs Charles; and Jeremy Leary took Charles and me in the Carriage to the Winisimet or East-Boston steam ferry boat. There we left Jerry and the Carriage to return home, and went over in a Hack from the Tremont House; and embarked in the British and North-American Royal mail Steam packet Acadia Captain Edward C. Miller, bound to Halifax Nova-Scotia, and Liverpool England— We met there 34 other passengers, all entire strangers to us, except a Son (George) of Coll. Thomas H. Perkins, going to England, and whom his father had accompanied to take leave of him at the ship— Josiah Quincy junr. Benjamin Russell, and W. W. Clapp. Mr Isaac T Smith gave me his card, and repeated an invitation. I had some time since received to deliver a Lecture next November before the New-York Lyceum. I said I had delayed answering the former application from unwillingness to decline and uncertainty whether I could comply with it. I feared this would not be in my power, but I would send a definitive answer after my return from this excursion— Mr Curtis was already on board the boat, and my trunk which Gillet the Stageman had brought in from Quincy; and sent on board— Two minutes before 12 O’Clock the Mail came on board, and the boat immediately cast off from her moorings at the wharf—passed by the Columbus line of battle ship lying in the stream, and glided down the bay with smooth water beneath, a gentle breeze around, and a glowing Sun above, at the rate of 9 1/2 knots an hour.— The wharf at East Boston whence we parted, and the line of wharves on the western side of the stream were crowded with Spectators, cheering with shouts the Steamer as she passed along The Steamers John W. Richmond, and General Lincoln, thronged with passengers escorted her down, the latter to just below Castle Island, the former to point Alderton and the Light at the entrance of the harbour, where they respectively took leave of her with reciprocated huzzas and returned to the City— And now vogue la Galere, East North East for Cape Sable; and before dark we had lost sight of the Boston State house, the blue hills, the Northern shores of Marblehead,—Gloucester and Cape-Ann, the South shore of Cohasset, Scituate and Marshfield; and were floating on the boundless expanse of waters— The day and Evening continued fair—the Sunset not altogether unclouded, but with a clear sky above— At 10 I retired to my berth N. 56. and turned in for the Night.

Quiet Night— Gentle breezes— The Sun was rising, not clear, not much beclouded when I went first upon deck— I had slept till day light— Mr Curtis and I have one State room, with berths N. 55. and 56 between us—he came to his berth in the Night and left it this morning, unperceived by me. The day was variable, cloudy and clear alternately with symptoms of approaching fogs but none present—moderate breezes, weather alternately chilly and mild. Sails alternately set and furled— Breakfast at 8. A.M— Luncheon at Noon. Dinner at 4. P.M— Tea at 7. and a range of Tumblers and Wine-glasses set on the tables, with wine and Spirits, and a Tea-kettle of boiling water and sugar, for messing till bed time. Below, Cards, Backgammon and draughts. I spent great part of the day, at intervals in our State room writing to my wife; a Letter, which I closed and sealed to have it ready to put into the Post Office immediately after our landing at Halifax— There are 37 passengers in the boat, 20 of whom are for Liverpool and 17 to stop at Halifax— Among them are a Boston family two men, Mrs and two Misses Andrews, Major Dunn of the British Army—Revd. Thomas R. Lambert, Chaplain of the Columbus Man of War—an Armenian Merchant from Smyrna, but who has resided several years in Boston name Jasigi (Joseph) Stephen—Binney, of Halifax and John H Crosskill Lieutt. in the 3d. Regiment of Halifax Militia— The ship is over 200 feet long. The rigging of the masts very slight, but much of it in iron chains instead of ropes— The Steam engines and boilers, are between the fore- and main masts, between which the very large chimney is also placed— There are berths and accommodations for 100 passengers— The ships company consists of 82 persons divided into three classes 1. for navigation 2 for the management of the Steam machinery— 3. For attendance on the passengers—about 20. at the kitchen and bed chamber service, with a Steward and Stewardess at their head— The table fare is magnificent and profuse—the dinner of four courses with a variety of fruits and wines— There is great order and discipline in the respective services and no interference with each other— Six waiting men at the dinner table moved in perfect harmony under the direction of the Steward— Great attention is paid to the cleanliness of the boat— The Engines are of 480 horse power— The iron, brass and woodwork neatly finished, and of infrangible solidity. Her burden is of 1200 tons, and she has now 600 tons of coal on board for the voyage to Liverpool— The consumption at her full speed is of about forty tons a day, and as she is lightened of the load the momentum of her speed is increased. She began on leaving the wharf yesterday at the rate of 9 1/2 knots an hour, which towards this Evening increased to ten. The course of the ship was E.N.E from Boston harbour till she turned Cape Sable at 2 this afternoon, and thence N.E. We did not see the cape, and barely discerned the Coast of Nova-Scotia as far distant as the eye could range, with here and there between us and the shore a fishing Schooner under sail— The threefold motion of the boat, pitching, rolling and thrilling was barely perceptible to me, but confined the Lady passengers to their berths and we did not see them.— The most talkative and amusing of our companions was Mr Jasigi.

I slept little, and from about two in the morning lying in my berth, heard the Pilot on the fore-castle giving his steering orders to the helmsman— Shortly after 3. a gun was fired upon deck which was returned from the shore; and just at 4. the boat was moored to the wharf at Halifax. I rose immediately, and as daylight came on viewed the river and harbour, and the opposite shore, where the small town of Dartmouth in a valley between the slopes of two hills covered with forests of pines forms a picturesque landscape— Halifax itself, like our towns of Haverhill, and New-London, and Georgetown, ranges along in streets ascending like stairs in lines parallel to the course of the river— As the Sun rose, Mr Samuel Cunard and his Son Edward came onboard, and invited us to breakfast with him at 8. In the meantime we landed and took lodgings at the Masonic Hall, kept by a man named Coblentz, said to be the best house of entertainment in the town— We breakfasted at Mr Cunard’s and there saw his four handsome daughters, one of whom two days since was married to a Captain of the 37th. Regiment, named Franklyn.— We here met also for the last time, and took leave of Captain Edward C. Miller, a Lieutenant in the British Navy, and Commander of the Royal Steam packet Acadia.— Half an hour after breakfast, Mr Cunard took us in his chariot, and introduced us to His Excellency Sir Colin Campbell, Lieutenant Governor, of the British Province of Nova-Scotia; who received us politely and invited us to dine with him at 7 this evening— The weather had become stormy, and the rain confined us some hours at the inn, which I was enabled to employ in writing. We met for one moment at the door of the inn Coll. Butler, who had been in 1816 one of the Schoolmates of my Sons at Ealing.— He was now about to embark in the Acadia, as a passenger to Liverpool. I had through the day a number of visitors, inhabitants of the town, and full of kind and courteous hospitality— Among them Mr Archibald, Attorney General and Speaker of the provincial house of Assembly, who was going immediately upon professional business to Cape-Breton; Mr John Fairbanks, son of a refugee from Framingham Massachusetts—Mr James Leander Starr, with whose Lady and her Sister, Miss Throckmorton of New-York, and a little daughter of Mrs Starr. I took a ride of an hour and a half in an open Barouche, in a circle of the country round the town— At 7. Mr Cunard came and took Mr Curtis and me in his Carriage to the Governors to dine. But my Son had been taken, with a severe sick head ache; and could not go with us— The dinner was splendid—served altogether on plate.— The company, eighteen chiefly military officers all in full uniform—Sir Colin wearing the Star of the Bath and the Medallion of Waterloo— Lord Charles Fitzroy appointed Governor of Prince Edward’s Island was there en bourgeois with Lady Mary his wife, another Lady, and a Son and daughter of Sir Colin. Between 9 and 10. a messenger came with advice that the Canadian Mails and Passengers had arrived from Picton, and that the Acadia was unmooring to depart for Liverpool, whereupon Mr Cunard and one of the guests were called out, and Mr Curtis and I took leave of Sir Colin and returned to our Inn.

The Steamer Unicorn was to have arrived here yesterday at 3. P.M with the Mails and Passengers from Quebec and Prince Edward’s Island, to go by the Acadia for Liverpool— She was to have departed hence this day to return to Quebec at Noon, and we had proposed to take passage in her.— Lord Charles Fitzroy with his family are here waiting to take passage in the Unicorn, to be landed at Charlottes town on Prince Edward’s Island— But on her passage from Quebec down the river Saint Lawrence she took ground and was detained twelve hours— Her Mails, and passengers were landed at Picton, and came thence by land 102 1/2 miles— They arrived at 9 last Evening and at 1/2 past 11. the Acadia departed for Liverpool— The Unicorn arrived at 8. this morning, and we were flattering ourselves that we should embark in her at Noon for Quebec. But her Engine took some damage by her grounding in the river, and she is detained here for a survey and repairs at least until next Tuesday; and perhaps longer. She is then to take Lord Fitzroy to his Government of Prince Edward’s Island, but will not proceed to Quebec until after the arrival from Liverpool here of the Britannia, expected on the 15th.— Our expedition to Quebec is therefore blown up, and we are put to our shifts to get home as we may— I had many kind visitors again this day among whom Mr Joseph Howe, and Mr Thomas Forrester, representatives of the County and town of Halifax in the general House of Assembly. Mr Howe invited us to dine with him at 6. O’Clock, and in the mean time they both took us a ride of nine miles to the head of the bay which runs up above Halifax, navigable, all the way up— Before going I called with my Son upon Mr Sampson Salter Blowers—a refugee from Boston—said to have turned shortly since, his hundredth birthday— He was the official prosecutor as the King’s attorney defender at Boston of Captain Preston and the Soldiers indicted for the Massacre of the 5th. of March 1770. of whom my father and Josiah Quincy were with him the Official defenders—the lawyers in that prosecution, on both sides sustaining the party to which they were opposed of Preston and the Soldiers— Mr Blowers came from Boston with the British troops, and never returned.— He is one of the Patriarchs of the Province of Nova-Scotia, and was successively Chief Justice of the Superior Court after being Attorney General, Speaker of the House of Assembly, Councillor, and sometime acting Governor— He is now in retirement, said to be wealthy, enjoying bodily health, but with all the faculties of the mind impaired— He received us courteously, and thanked us for calling upon him. I told him I was the son of John Adams whom he formerly knew, but he made no answer— I introduced my Son to him and he enquired what was his age. I said we had arrived in the Steamer Acadia from Boston; he said that was his native place, and he had always retained his affection for it, and rejoiced in its prosperity— He had said it would prosper, and believed it was now the most prosperous place in North-America; and this place was the next— We dined with Mr Howe— His wife a Mrs Godfrey, Mr Howe’s brother, Mr Forrester and Mr Bell the other member from Halifax in the House of Assembly, were of the company— Mr Howe accompanied us to our lodgings, and gave us a Letter of introduction toHaliburton, author of Sam Slick, residing at Windsor, for which we took seats in the Stage to depart at 6 to-morrow morning.

Disappointed in the purpose of embarking in the Unicorn for Quebec, we concluded to return home, by the way of Annapolis and the Province of New-Brunswick.— We took the Stage first for Windsor, and left our lodgings at the Masonic Hall, at 6 this morning with four travelling companions; Mr John Frothingham a native of New-England, and merchant of Montreal in Canada, with his son Frederic a youth of about 17. and a Bostonian namedsettled as a merchant at Mayaguez in the Island of Porto Rico, about 30 years of age, with his wife, travelling for their health.— We came to Windsor 45 Miles from Halifax in three Stages of 17. 15. and 13 miles with the same Carriage and driver twice changing horses— We reached Windsor about 1. P.M. but found no Steamer there nor any expectation of one before next Tuesday—wherefore, we determined to proceed immediately, and came on 13 miles to Gasperaux river and ten miles further to Kentville, which is a part of the township of Horton. We landed just at Sunset having travelled 68 miles, in one Carriage, and with one driver— The first forty miles of the road are nearly one continued forest of what the Germans call needle wood trees—white and pitch pine, cedar, spruce, fir and Larch; with intermixture of white and yellow, birch, beech, maple, and here and there, red and grey Oak— Many of the trees were tall and straight, but none of them large— The soil generally sand or rock, with few settlements on the road— One country seat between Halifax and Windsor, belonging to the Honourable Thomas Nickleson Jeffery the Senior member of the Executive Council, was the only mansion the elegance of which and of the ground around it, indicated opulence— Scarcely one village on the road—but at distances of a quarter or half mile from each other single farm-houses with elderly looking barns, were surrounded with green pastures, indifferent apple-orchards, a stout and strong breed of horned cattle; a few sorry horses, pigs and swine of ordinary size— Turkies and ducks not remarkable—fine looking and numerous flocks of geese, and dunghill fowls in abundance— Very few ragged and no squalid looking persons, and no beggars— The general aspect is of a healthy quiet and contented population. The children especially remarkable for fair complections handsome faces, and rosy cheeks— On approaching Windsor, and part of the way thence to Kentville, the soil is more fertile; the country much more cleared of wood and the farms more productive— The recollection that Halifax leaves upon the mind of the traveller, is of a very moderately prospering, and not enterprizing city. A garrison of three regiments of infantry 8th. 23d. and 37th. with a Corps of Artillery and of Engineers, gives it the appearance of a City besieged, and the accomodations for the army and navy account for its population, much more than any of its adaptations for commercial enterprize which are very small. As we stop’d at Windsor only to change our horses we had no opportunity to deliver our Letter of introduction to judge Haliburton— At Windsor we saw a large ship of 600 tons upon the Stocks— It is one of the Ports upon the bay of Fundy, in Steam boat communication with St. Johns, New Brunswick.

The Stages in this Province do not travel on the Sabbath and we were necessarily detained here this day; much to my satisfaction, for I was glad to escape from the overflowing civilities of Halifax, before we could be made conscious that they were burdensome to those who paid them, and as time advances, I long more and more for one day of repose in seven— After breakfast this morning my first enquiry was for a Church where we might attend public worship and were informed of a presbyterian Church two miles and an episcopal church four miles distant both in the town of Cornwallis, and of a methodist church nearer, where there would be service in the afternoon— Sallying out to walk to the presbyterian church we soon met Mr Thomas Hardy a Scotchman and keeper of the public school at Kentville, who walked some way with us, and Mr James D. Harris a judge of the inferior Court and Sessions of the Peace for King’s County who overtook us in his gig, and invited me to take a seat with him, which I did. He took me to the episcopal church, where he and his family attend, and where the Revd. H. L. Owen read the morning service of the Church of England for the 12th. Sunday after trinity and preached a short Sermon from Habakkuk 2.15. “Wo unto him that giveth his neighbour drink, that puttest thy bottle to him, and makest him drunken also, that thou mayest look on their nakedness.” (mark the grammatical transposition of persons, to the verbs—) a plain and sensible discourse against drunkenness, in which the obvious arguments against that vice, were illustrated by quotations from Scripture preceptive and exemplary; not excepting Noah, Lot, and David.— The preachers reading and delivery were very monotonous and sluggish— The Congregation was small but of respectable appearance— Judge Harris’s wife and part of his family were there. He has six sons and three daughters.— His father was one of the refugee, or as they prefer to be called loyalist settlers of Nova-Scotia in 1783. immediately after the close of the revolutionary War— Mr Harris came from Connecticut, a child—he is a judge, and a private Banker; but he told me he had never been a member of the assembly, nor offered himself as a candidate; having no relish for public life. Mr Owen is settled in the neighbouring town of Aylesford; but was accidentally at Cornwallis, returning from a visit to Halifax— He gave notice that there would be divine service at this Church this day fortnight. Judge Harris took me home in his gig, with his son William a boy about 8 years old.— My companions stopped at the Presbyterian church. I had scarcely returned to our inn, when a Doctor W. B. Webster called and invited me with Mr Curtis and my son to ride with him in his Carryall to see a dam and sluice in Cornwallis constructed at an expence of 5000 pounds currency to dike out the waters of the river. we accordingly took the ride and then took tea at his fathers house where he resides. The father is a loyalist emigrant from Connecticut, and a tory of the first water as is a younger brother—he himself is of the popular party— We returned about 10. to our inn.

Our Stage carriage and driver were both changed this morning to our disadvantage, but the substitutes brought us safely in the course of the day from Kentville to Annapolis, 60 miles, over a road the first part of which was heavy with sand, and the last hilly and studded with rocks; but altogether a very good road— We had besides our company from Halifax, an outside passenger taken up on Saturday at Windsor, and Mr John Whidden, Clerk of the House of Assembly, and now a Candidate for election as a member of the house—for there is an election to be held in November, and we are told that it will be generally and warmly contested— The Government and popular parties are strongly marked and ardently opposed to each other— Dr Webster told us last Evening that his father and brother were Government men, but that he was of the popular party— This Dr Webster is what the French call an original, and the English an oddity. Curiosity and mobility seem to be the characteristics of his temper, without depths of observation or brilliancy of imagination— His motive for taking us to see the Cornwallis dam yesterday, with the invitation to tea at his father’s house, must have been pure kindness and hospitality— He has a taste also for natural history, and shewed us a number of birds stuffed and minerals indigenous in this Province; all collected by himself. We left Kentville which is a part of the township of Horton, named from the late Duke of Kent, after his death at half past 6 this morning, with an accession of two outside passengers to our company, and an exchange of a very good carriage for one of doubtful solidity and unpromising appearance; but which brought us however safely to Annapolis with the setting Sun— The first stage was of 17 miles to Crane’s, that being the name of the man who keeps the house—there we had a good breakfast, and the house though standing alone had a neat and comfortable aspect— The sound of a spinning wheel in a room adjoining to that where we breakfasted brought back sixty years or more of reminiscences familiar to my childhood, but which from that time have never been revived— To my Son it was an unwonted and unpleasant sound, but to Mr Curtis it was as to me a pleasing revival of incidents in early life long since passed away.— From this place we proceeded by a stage of 12 miles to Gibbons; another of 17 miles to Bridgetown, a small and neat looking village, but where there was no dinner in preparation for Stage passengers, and we took up with a collation or lunch of bread and cheese and a bottle of nut brown ale— Here we crossed a lofty bridge, necessarily so from the common rise and fall of the river at the place which is of more than thirty feet of the tide from the bay of Fundy— Our last stage of the day was 15 miles to Annapolis, the Old French Settlement of Port Royal, and formerly the chief town in the Province. No trace of France is now seen in it; nor would one imagine it to be a capital of any colony—but it is a good looking village, where we find comfortable lodgings though at two different houses; and the Steamer Maid of the Mist, to depart to-morrow Morning for the City of St. John in the Province of New-Brunswick.

div.dateline: Annapolis, Nova Scotia— St. John, New-Brunswick 8 September 1840.
div.p: Our ride yesterday was through a country much resembling that which he had traversed on Saturday— The first part over a heavy sand, and the latter part, through pine clad hills, interspersed with fertile vallies and solitary farmhouses around which we seldom failed to see oxen and cows of large size and in good condition— Fine looking sheep— Flocks of Turkies, Geese and dunghill fowls in abundance— Swine, not so numerous; nor of breeds so choice, yet good looking. Altogether the appearance of the Country, much like that of the interior of Massachusetts sixty years ago— This morning before our departure a gentleman called on me at the inn, and announced himself as a Son of my old and valued friend Benjamin Pickman, heretofore of Salem, now residing in Boston— He has been settled here, he told me about eight years in consequence of having married a Lady of this place, or as Mr Curtis conjectures because he inherited some of his Grandfather Pickman’s sentiments and opinions— We met here also last evening a Scottish Gentleman of the name of Smith, with his arm in a sling from some recent accident, with which I sympathised, according to Swift’s But should some neighbour feel a pain, just in the parts where I complain &c— He told us he had crossed the atlantic 13 times; one of which last year in the British Queen. He was visited while we were at supper by a young man, collector at the Port of Digby, a nephew of Sir Colin Campbell; and who came down with us in the Steamer this morning to that place, where he landed as did several other passengers, while others came on board there— Among them was a tall elderly, cheerless looking Indian, and a young stout, handsome, active ship carpenter from the settlement at Clare about twelve miles from Digby, the still existing remnants of the old Acadian neutral French— We anchored for about an hour at Digby 18 miles from Annapolis whence we had departed, between 7. and 8 this morning— The collector of the Port, brought on board, and lent us Thomas C. Haliburton’s History of Nova-Scotia, which he had casually mentioned in conversation with Mr Frothingham— He requested that the books might be left with Captain Hennenbury, in the Steam boat, to be returned to him when she came back. I would have purchased the books, but he had not a copy to spare— I occupied no small portion of the passage across the Bay of Fundy, in turning over the pages of the first Volume of this Book— The passage between Annapolis and Digby is a narrow basin, like a river broken in from the Bay of Fundy, through a passage between two rocky cliffs not half a mile wide or long. The course from this gap over the Bay of Fundy to St. John is directly North 36 miles.— We had left Kentville yesterday morning, with rain and mist and dark smoky clouds hanging over the sides of all the hills, but it cleared away by noon, and we had a clear night at Annapolis, and a bright Sun this morning— We opened upon the Bay of Fundy about 11. A.M. and could barely discern the opposite coast of New-Brunswick like far off mountains turning into clouds. The Steamer maid of the mist is small and slow and growing old; but the day was fair and without fog, though clouding up, and with a freshening breeze till 5 p.m. when we landed at the wharf in the City of St. John. The gradual receding of the Coast of Nova-Scotia, with the corresponding rise and approach of that of New-Brunswick had a pleasing effect upon the spirits but the rapid tides of the Bay produced a swell which with the briskness of the breeze sickened some of our passengers— A family from Boston a man, his wife, and five boys, from 4 to 12 years old, were among them. We took our lodgings at the St John’s Hotel. named La Hain—

I rose this morning an hour before day-light, and wrote till breakfast time, immediately after which Mr A. W. Whipple, and Mr M. H. Perley, inhabitants of the City, visited us, and offered their services, to shew us any of its objects of curiosity.— They took us first to the Officers barracks of the 69th. regiment of British infantry which is stationed at this place. They introduced us to Captain Blackburne the Senoir Captain in command The Colonel being upon a tour in the States, and now at Boston; and the Major gone home to England on leave— Captain Blackburne is a modest and very gentlemanly man, of pleasing deportment, and courteous manners, without affectation, studiously but not fawningly civil— He and several Officers with him shewed us the barracks of the soldiers; their mode of living, their muskets, which he said were not equal to ours, and the curious furniture of their knapsacks, a list of the articles composing which I was tempted to ask, to compare with ours, but refrained— We saw the apartments in which the Soldiers lodge, six, eight or ten in a room, the apartment where they mess—the kitchen where their food is cooked, and the meat and vegetables, in preparation for their dinner.— All which was neat, cleanly, economical, and comfortable— Also the hospital where in two chambers were the sick men in their beds; one of the chambers containing only the cases of ophthalmia which Captain Blackburne told us was a disease more common among the troops than all others put together. He took us also to the room where the musical band were practicing under the direction of the band master; and they regaled us with several beautiful marches and airs conducting with Kate Kearney— From the Barracks we went to the reading room where our names were entered—to the building now in process of erection for a City Hall and Exchange, and to the foundations laid for a large Custom-house— Mr Whipple then took Mr Curtis and me, [(]while Charles staid behind to write a letter home) to a saw-mill on the river two miles above the City, where we saw the operations of sawing logs in to boards and blocks into shingles— On our return to the Hotel, we were visited by multitudes of the Citizens of the place, among whom the Recorder, who in the absence of the Mayor welcomed me to the City, with an offer of a public dinner which I declined, as we are to depart to morrow Morning.— We dined with Captain Blackburne, and the Officers of the 69th. regiment at their barracks about 20 in number, among whom the names of Dalgetty and Kearney, and a Lieutenant Lord Glamis, son of the Earl of Strathmore were the only ones that I remember— Mr Whipple was the only stranger except ourselves.— They toasted the Queen and the President of the United States— Captain Blackburne complimented me, for which I returned thanks and gave the 69th. Regiment, and then the Duke of Wellington— We came home before 11.

At 1/2 past 6 this morning we left the City of St John literally built upon a rock, and said now to contain upwards of 33 thousand inhabitants— We came in a Coach from the inn, to Indian town two miles above the City; and there embarked in the Steamer New-Brunswick, and ascended the river St. John to Fredericton, the seat of Government of the Province 90 Miles— There was a heavy rain all the morning, and the boat was detained a full hour by falling foul of a raft close above the wharf whence we departed— The course of the river is first North, then North-east, then North, Northwest and North North West about 12 or 13 miles each town—about half way up lies on the western bank of the river, Gagetown, named I suppose from General Gage, and the only village settlement, between the City and the seat of Government. The Banks of the river near St. John are on both sides steep—lofty and precipitous rocks covered with seemingly impenetrable forests, but after the first turn the hills fall a way to distances sometimes of a mile or more with intervale lands of great fertility with solitary farm houses, small barns and stacks of hay piled upon stakes to preserve them from the tides— The face of the river’s banks all the way poor but comfortable—the landscapes fair and varied but neither endowed by nature with sublimity nor cultivated into the beauty of art; between Gagetown and the eastern bank there is an island, which interrupts it from the view so that we saw it only from below and from above.— About 7 miles below Fredericton, there is another Island with a shoal and a bar, which goes wholly across the river, and where the water is so shallow that our boat touched the ground and rubbed over it— There were as passengers in the boat, named Babbit and Worden, men approaching 70. both of whom came with their fathers; loyalists from New-York in 1783— Also Major Cairnes of the 37th regiment stationed at Fredericton who introduced himself to me with numerous civilities and kind attentions—he introduced me to Mrs Shore, a Lady of elegant manners and accomplishments wife of a civil and military officer of high distinction in the Province, also a passenger in the boat—as were Captain Ross of the 37th. regiment and several other Officers— We landed at Fredericton just after Sunset, and took lodgings at Jackson’s Hotel; where within half an hour, I received a note from his Excellency Sir John Harvey, Major General, and Lieutenant Governor of the Province of New-Brunswick, with the most obliging offers of service, horses and a kind invitation to us to dine with him to-morrow— Charles answered his note with many thanks and acceptance of his invitation to dinner— We found at Jackson’s hotel Signor Blitz, who gave us tickets of admission to his exhibition of ventriloquism, and of leger de main. We accordingly took tickets and attended— As we returned to the Hotel we were met by Captain Tryon, the Governor’s Aid de Camp and Son in Law—with a second note of invitation, and offer of a Carriage, and we promised to call on the Governor at 11. to morrow morning— We received also an invitation from Major Cairnes and the Officers of the 37th Regiment to dine with them the day after to-morrow.

Early this morning we had a visit from Mr Black, Mayor of St John who expressed his regret that he had been accidentally here, absent from the city, while we were there; and where he would have been happy to have shewn us any attentions, which could make our visit to the place agreeable. He embarked to return home this morning— We had visits also last Evening, and this morning from six or seven Indians two of whom named John Francis—and Neptune—were of our Passamaquoddy tribe, and the rest of the St. John’s or Micmac tribe within this province. They had all been to a general gathering of Indian tribes held in Canada, last month at the invitation of the British Canadian Government for the preservation of Peace. John Francis is the Governor of the Passamaquoddy Indians, and Neptune, who speaks a little English acted as interpreter. They wanted a certificate or paper in the nature of a Passport from me, and said last Night that they were to have one this morning from Sir John Harvey— I asked Neptune if they had got their certificate from Sir John this morning— He said he was too busy.— I told him that I had been, but was no longer a Chief in my own Country, and that a certificate or passport from me, would be of no sort of use to them— The paper of advice from the Canadian Indians which they shewed to me, was an earnest exhortation to them, to adhere inflexibly to the roman Catholic religion, and not to sell one inch of their Lands— On another paper, there was a statement of the motive of their Journey, and a contribution of £5. annexed to the name of Sir John Harvey, upon their journey to Canada in July; from which they are now returning.— The parade of the 36th regiment was to have been at 10. this morning; but there was rain and a lowering sky and there was no parade. At 11. we went in a Carriage to the Government house, where we were received, with great cordiality by Sir John Harvey— He invited us to take a ride with him to view the country round and to name the hour— I named 2. p.m. he said he should then be at leisure, and had sent for Signor Blitz to come and exhibit before his family— We returned to the Hotel, and called at the House of Major Cairnes to return his visit— Not at home— A Committee of 3. Gentlemen came and invited us to visit the reading room which we did at 5 O’Clock p.m. Sir John Harvey’s open waggon had called and taken us to the Government House at 2.— Signor Blitz there performed some of his wondrous works, before the family— Captain Tryon’s little daughter, 3 years old, on Lady Harvey’s lap, and calling the Governor papa mine— Servants called in to see the show. Sir John then shewed us round his grounds; laid out with taste and elegance along the banks of the river— Kitchen Garden well cultivated— He then rode with us about 3 miles up and 2 miles down, on the banks of the river, and landed us at our lodgings at 4. We went with Mr Street the Solicitor General to the Province house; the Legislative and Judicial Mansion— Undergoing repairs— Portraits of George the 3d. Queen Charlotte, and Lord Glenelg— At 5. we visited the reading-room—Newspapers—Featherstonhaugh and Mudge’s Report and Maps. Dined with Sir John Harvey at 7. Captain and Mrs Tryon— Lieutenant Harvey. Mr and Mrs Shore— Major and Mrs Cairnes. Evening party and Ball— Numerous Ladies— Many Officers— Captains Ross and Hogshaw— Beverley Robertson and brothers— Dancing— Waltzing. Home to our lodgings at Midnight.

At 7 this morning after breakfasting at our lodgings, Jackson’s Hotel at Fredericton we started in the Stage for Woodstock. The river above Fredericton is not navigable for Steamboats; but the road runs all along as close as possible on the banks of the river; nearly the first halfway on the South, and the rest on the North bank of the river— We were 12 passengers in the Stage, 9 of whom inside, including 2 women— The Stage was old and crazy. When we stopped at the Post Office warned our driver that she would break down, and one of the springs on which the thorough braces were supported was loosened— We nevertheless proceeded—the first Stage was of 18 miles— 35 miles from Fredericton there was a ferry to cross— The Stage and four horses crossed in a flat bottom boat, to serve which there were two ferrymen only— The passengers had alighted from the Stage, and the approach to the landing place was inaccessible to them for the mud.— There was a small boat at hand, grounded on the bank, with a foot deep of water at the bottom— Some of our fellow passengers baled out the water, and one of them rowed us, with crosshanded oars over the river— All save one, a Frenchman, named Baire; from the disputed territory at Madawaska—jumped into a small canoe, and paddled himself over.— The road thence for seven miles was heavy with hills, deep with sand and studded with rocks; through a region covered with forests of pine, cedar, spruce, fir, and hemlock, a primitive growth tall and slender, with here and there small birch, beech and maple and rarely red and grey oak interspersed with burnt stumps, and tall strip’d trunks of pines looking like the stacks of chimneys of burnt dwelling houses.— Then prostrate pines, fit for the masts of some high ammiral?, with their roots torn up from the soil like the side wall of a mud built hovel; or fallen till sustained by the dividing branches of other yet standing trees Here and there a small cleared lot, with a small house, and perhaps a barn, cattle, sheep and domestic fowls— The proportion of dead trunks of trees standing in the midst of others, gives the whole landscape an appearance of desolation, and the almost total absence of birds, adds a darker gloom to the solitude of the wild. But the river flows through all this scenery; with strings of narrow long islands, most of which are cultivated and present an aspect of fertility. 42 miles from Fredericton, we dined at the house of a Scotchman name Munro.— We got a tolerably good dinner to which our driver sat down with us.— We had witnessed no such usage in Nova-Scotia. The carriage had broken down two or three times, and at Munro’s, was detained nearly two hours for a blacksmith’s repairs— Mr Munro with much complaisance told me that he had heard me spoken of very respectfully, in the ould country— We had at one stage after dinner, a third pair of horses tackled to the Stage.— The accidents we met with, were fortunately without hurt to our persons, but delayed our progress till after dark— But the weather which had been rainy and gloomy cleared off towards Night, leaving bright moonshine— We crossed without difficulty at 8 the second ferry five miles from Woodstock; and the creek there, to Mrs Grover’s house at 9. She is a widow, born at Halifax, and says she kept the Masonic Hall at that place, till five years ago, when he died—after which she came here with her mother, who is yet living. She has also a Sister married here— We found on our arrival here a fire made in the common parlour— The first we have met since we left Boston.

div.dateline: Woodstock. New Brunswick— Houlton, Maine 13. September 1840.
div.p: There was a frost last Night, and frost ice this morning. Mr Baire the Frenchman from Madawaska, went off this morning in the stage for that place— An open waggon with 3. Seats, for 6 persons including the driver— There were 8 persons in it, and an enormous load of baggage, which Mr Baire called le butin, before they left the tavern door; and they were to take up two passengers more. Mr Baire had been silent all day yesterday in the Stage, of which I had not known the cause— On finding that he was French, I spoke to him in that language, and found him very willing to converse and apparently glad to talk; but I had so little time for discourse with him that I learnt very little about the Madawaska settlement— On enquiring for an opportunity to attend public worship we found there were in the neighbourhood of our Inn two Churches—one Episcopal Church of England—the other, Wesleyan Methodist; but that the ministers of both were absent, and that there would be no divine service at either. Afterwards however, Mr English, brother in Law to Mrs Grover, and the Postmaster of the place, came and accompanied us to the Methodist Church, where a young man, a native of the Province (vulgarly called a blue nose) named George Williams, performed the services of prayer, and giving out by semi-couplets the hymns to be sung, and read a Sermon of John Wesley from Luke 12.7. “Even the hairs of your head are numbered.” A sensible and not enthusiastic discourse upon a general, and particular Providence— Mr Williams repeated the prayers with fluency, but is a very indifferent reader.— The Revd. Mr Johnson was the regular preacher, and Mr Williams announced that he would preach the next Sunday— The Church is small, but very neat—the congregation not numerous, but well dressed, of grave and decent demeanour, and highly respectable in appearance— We dined at Woodstock. Mrs Grover our hostess, and her family, a son and daughter dined with us— The weather being fair, and an open waggon the only Stage carriage to Houlton, we concluded to take the ride this afternoon, to escape the chance of rain to-morrow Morning— We started at 3 p.m in a Carryall with 3 seats for 6 persons, a pair of horses and a yankee driver. We had 12 miles of good road; through a wilderness of spruce, pine, birch and fir woods to Houlton where we arrived at 5. O’Clock— The dividing line between the Province of New-Brunswick and the State of Maine is about 2 miles short of Houlton, and just before we reached it, a solitary, long, narrow, and apparently empty house, separated by three partitions, our driver told us was a smuggling shop—on the American side; near the line were two Cash stores.— We saw the boundary line, and the summits of Mars Hill, at the distance of 30. Miles— About an hour after us, arrived at the same Inn Major Graham one of the U.S. Commissioners to survey the boundary line; with Lieutt. T. J. Lee and a surveying party— Coll. Pierce and Major Kirby of the Regiment stationed here, called upon us this Evening. Dr Lawson, and five other Officers, are boarders in the House. I met in front of the house, Mr Houlton, after whom the place was named, and had some conversation with him— Maine election to-morrow— Clear Sunset.

Notwithstanding the fair promise of last Evening’s Sunset, there was a copious rain in the night, and through the greatest part of this day; with occasional intervals, but not a glimpse of the Sun— I rose early, and wrote by candlelight more than two hours— Immediately after breakfast, General Abraham Eustis, commanding the first Regiment of U.S. Artillery stationed at Houlton, called on me, and invited us to visit the barracks— I accordingly walked with him to them and as we approached them, a salute of 13 guns was fired, which he told me was intended for me— The Officers of the Regiment were introduced to me, and the men were ordered out for parade— General Eustis observing that I had been heretofore the commander in chief of the armies of the United States, enquired if I would review the troops— I answered that being no longer in the capacity of Commander in Chief I should ask to be excused from that service, to which he readily assented— The regiment was however paraded, and went through the exercise and marching with great accuracy and precision. I said to the general that they were quite as expert and rapid in their movements as any part that I had seen of the British army— He said the scarlet coat had an advantage over the blue—immediately after the parade, one of the companies were marched off to repair to Eastport and the whole corps escorted them about a mile on their way— Another company is to march the day after to morrow for Portland. There have been eight companies here, while there is room at the barracks only for six— Several of the Officers have therefore been obliged—to board at the Inn, which has a bad effect on the discipline. General Eustis said he had deeply regretted that Coll. Pierce and Major Kirby had visited me last Evening—that they had both returned to the barracks under a very high degree of excitement— I said I had not observed any thing of it, at which he said he was surprized. They were the only two Officers in the regiment liable to such susceptibilities— We visited Mrs Eustis a Lady from South Carolina—and whom the climate of Houlton does not suit. The General said, he had thought as badly of the place, before he came to the place, as was possible; but had found it much worse than he had anticipated— He has lost since last May 250 men by desertion, and there are not 500. men now here— We returned and dined at the Inn— It is the annual and congressional election day at Houlton, and throughout the State of Maine— The Barmaid at our inn was told that a man who had offered to vote, had been rejected as an Alien— An Alien? what’s that?— A blue nose— Well, said she, I hope Mr Harrison will be chosen President of the United States next November and if he is not, I will leave this place— At 3. p.m we left Houlton in the Stage for Bangor— We had as travelling companions Lieutenant Wayne, a son of the judge of the U.S. Supreme Court—a Soldier this day discharged and going to New-York; and a woman weighing at least 200 lb avoir du pois, and with a face for one of Macbeth’s witches— We came in heavy rain, through a dreary wilderness 25 miles to Hainesville; a solitary house, and a new Landlord, who served us up Moose, killed by an Indian, and gave me a log-cabin, down East for a bed room to sleep in—

The rain continued through the Night and all this Morning. At half past two we were summoned from our log-cabin beds, and proceeded 20 Miles to breakfast at Mattawamkeag. Our Amazon fellow-passenger came no farther than Hainesville, where she had until recently been the keeper of the house at which we lodged—a good (not a fair[)] sample of the female pioneer of the wilderness.— From Mattawamkeag, we came a 9 mile stage to Lincoln. 13 miles to Enfield. 16 to the place where we dined—then 16 toand 16 to Bangor, where at half past 7 in the Evening, we alighted at the Bangor Hotel, the best public house we have seen since we left Boston— We travelled this day ninety miles, almost entirely through a wilderness, covered with spruce, pine, fir, and birch trees resembling exactly what we had seen in Nova-Scotia, and in ascending the river St. John— There was one extensive tract, known by the name of the burnt district, where great ravages have been committed by fire among the woods— The lots of ground covered with stumps from 3 to four feet high, looking like a huge bowling green with the nine pins set up in order upon it were numerous. Many of the trees appeared to have been burnt off. The living trees were lofty, with stems of no unreasonable size, but perfectly straight, from 30 to 50 feet high, and suitable for masts of different sizes— Scarcely any ground cleared, and scarcely an attempt to eradicating the stumps. In some places there was grain, rye or Indian corn or grass on the soil, where the stumps were still standing— We came part of the way, along near the Bank of the Penobscot river, on which Bangor is situated— Yesterday was the election day—throughout the State of Maine, and at every stage at which we stopp’d, and every Post-Office by which we passed we witnessed great excitement of anxious curiosity to learn how the vote of yesterday had gone in the towns through which we passed.— At one town, Lincoln, the Postmaster was in fine Spirits, and said they were looking up; because the democrats had gained 4 votes upon the election in 1838—that of 1839. not having been seriously contested—but in all the other towns the gain had been on the whig side—much to the annoyance of our driver and of most of the Postmasters— About 20 Miles short of Bangor, we took up as passengers a man named Haines, and a young man, a son of Professor Cleveland who said he had come 150 miles, for the single purpose of depositing his vote, and we shall elect Fairfield, said he, by 5000 majority—ten minutes after he said—if we do not carry Fairfield by more than 2000 majority I will go for Harrison in November— Shortly after he asked my Son, if he was acquainted with John Quincy Adams—upon which Charles pointed to me, and said that’s he—upon which he offered me his hand which I readily took. At the Bangor house they shewed me into the Ladies parlour, where there were two ladies and a gentleman— In a few minutes the room filled up with visitors, all strangers among whom were Mr Carr the Mayor of the City—Edward Kent, Ex-Governor and now a candidate for election to that Office; and George Barrell Moody, both Classmates at Cambridge of my dear departed son George—Dr Benjamin Dixon Bartlett, a graduate of 1810—Mr Jerome, formerly of Boston and others almost numberless— Mr Carr the Mayor invited me to receive the visits and greetings of the Citizens generally, to which I assented appointing the hour of 10. O’Clock to-morrow Morning, but I said I must ask them to excuse me from addressing them in a speech.

The Bangor Hotel, is one of the public houses, set up in many of our large towns in imitation of the Tremont house at Boston, and in point of accommodation for lodgers is the best that I have yet visited— At half past seven the lodgers were roused to breakfast, by the sound of the Gong, a very noisy and discordant substitute for the Bell.— The two Ladies and the Gentleman whom I had found in the Ladies parlour last evening were at the breakfast table, and I apologized to them for the interruption and breaking up of their musical party by the numerous visitors who came in.— At 10. O’Clock, the Mayor, Mr Carr came, and proposed to me to receive the Citizens who wished to see, and shake hands with me, in a large upper dancing hall in the Hotel to which I assented— There for about half an hour, I received and shook hands with all that came—two or three hundred— They were named as they came, but were all strangers, not one of whose names I can recollect— Many others came merely to look on, and to hear.— They soon filled the hall, and I saw it was impossible to dismiss them without an Address— I told the Mayor that although I had requested to be excused from addressing the Citizens to day; yet as they were now assembled, I could not possibly part from them after this meeting without saying a few words; whereupon, a gentleman named M’Gaw, I suppose some City Officer, in a style far more complimentary than agreeable to me; and I mounted on a Sopha at one end of the Hall, and spoke for about an hour and a half to the People— I gave them my reasons for the request I had made to the Mayor to be excused from addressing them in public— My position as an Ex-president of the U.S. and as possibly a Candidate for re-election as a member of Congress— Reasons for which I had declined attending any of the large public meetings which have been held within the year, from that of Baltimore last May, to that of Bunker hill last week— I should continue to decline attending all such meetings in future, and should now confine myself to two topics specially interesting to the People of the State of Maine, and to myself— I then rectified certain misrepresentations of my opinions made by Joshua A. Lowell, a member of the present delegation from Maine in Congress, and spoke with disgust of Featherstonhaugh’s recent report on the North-eastern boundary— The crowd still collected in the Hall, and the Mayor proposed to me to adjourn to the steps of the House for fear of breaking down the Hall— I preferred closing my discourse, which I did with an abundance of cheering. Then at 12. O’Clock Mr Pierce accompanied me to visit Mr Philip Coombs; a heavy lame invalid old gentleman, whom more than fifty years ago I had known as a tall, slender, active, sprightly young man, living at his father’s house at Newburyport. Mrs Coombs is a relation of the Harrod family. At 1/2 past 1. we dined, and here met Ezekiel Whitman, heretofore a member of Congress from the State of Maine and now a judge—and here we parted from our fellow traveller Lieutenant Wayne—from 4 to 5 I rode to the heights above the City with Mr Carr the Mayor and several others— The view of the city, and the prospects around it from these heights are extremely beautiful— At 5 we visited at Mrs Hammett’s. Mrs Hammett is a niece of Mrs. Cushing the wife of Judge William Cushing once of Scituate. Mrs Cushing was an intimate friend of my mother, and Mrs Hammett has the whole collection of my mother’s Letters to her— Here I met Mr Hedge the Minister— Tea party at Mr Pierce’s, and from 1/2 past 7 to 10. I received visits from the Ladies, at the Hotel. Mr and Mrs Jerome—Major Freeman from Boston. Mrs Fearon requested two autograph signatures. Note and Books from E. F. Duren— Packed up— Bed past 1. A.M—

Up again at four O’Clock this morning. At 5 we embarked in the Steamer Bangor Captain Howes for Portland, and Boston— That was the hour at which she should have departed from the wharf: but although the Night had been clear, and the Sun rose bright, with the Sun there came up a thick fog and there was a bar of a few miles below the City, to pass which it was expedient to wait for the flood tide. It was near 7. when we loosened from the wharf with a multitude of passengers—Men—women and children, among whom as sedom fails in a Steamer one, excessively fractious and troublesome baby— Judge Whitman, U.S. District judge Ashur Ware, and judge William Pitt Preble were also of the company— They all live at Portland and have been a fortnight at Bangor upon an arbitration— Mr Fessenden, an elderly member of the bar at Portland, father of the young man just elected to the 27th Congress in the place of Albert Smith was also of the party, and Mr Dwinell a Gentleman to whom we were indebted for many civilities yesterday, but of whom I know nothing further— It is indeed impossible to conceive of the confusion of the mind, and forgetfulness of names upon the presentation of hundreds of persons at one time— In descending the Penobscot river, we passed first by Frankfort on the right and Bucksport on the left bank of the river— I had yesterday several visitors from Brewer; on the opposite side of the river to Bangor.— Frankfort is about 7 and Bucksport 9 miles below— As we approached Frankfort, guns were fired from the shore, and bells were rung—a crowd of people were assembled on the wharf, who as we parted from it gave three cheers— I supposed it a rejoicing of the whigs at their election victory— As we approached Bucksport, the firing of guns and ringing of bells were repeated— Judge Whitman said to me, that is for you— I said surely not—but for the whig victory— As we parted from the wharf the cheering was a hearty shout— The right of petition—the right of petition—huzza for the man who sustains the right of petition—left no doubt of the meaning of the guns and bells— It was a happy moment leaving me to lament to how little purpose I had defended the right of petition.— We afterwards passed by Waldo, and Prospect, Belfast and Castine on opposite sides at the mouth of Penobscot river and opening to the Bay.— Then Lincolnville and Thomaston—through the whole day, sudden and entire alternations of clear, bright Sunshine, and of impenetrable and perplexing fogs disclosed and concealed some of the most beautiful scenery upon earth— For several hours from 9. A.M. till noon there was nothing beyon the vessel to be seen, and I retired to a birth in the lower cabin and ruminated but did not sleep— We afterwards passed the Fox-islands, numerous ledges of rocks— Seguin island light—Pemmaquid point, and just at Sunset went in to Boothbay harbour and anchored at Townsend. Captain Howes was afraid to proceed in the Night, with a fog he said as dense as he had ever seen— Within half an hour after Sunset however the fog cleared away, and the anchor was soon weighed at 8. p.m. we passed by the mouths of the Sheepscut and Kennebeck rivers and Cape Smallpoint— I had a long conversation upon political topics with Mr Fessenden; and then retired without undressing to a couch in the lower cabin, where I slept till awaked by the fastening of the Steamer to the wharf at Portland, precisely at One, in the Morning.

div.dateline: Portland. Maine— Portsmouth New Hampshire 18. September 1840.
div.p: We landed from the Steamer Bangor, on the wharf at Portland at one O’Clock this morning, and took lodgings at the Cumberland House; another good imitation of the Tremont— I went immediately to bed and slept till half past 6. when I rose in sound health, and fresh from the fatigues of four preceding days— At half past 7. we breakfasted at the ordinary, and there met Mr Virgil D. Parris a member of the present Congress from Maine, but who has just failed as a candidate for re-election— We had barely breakfasted, when Mr C. A. Daveis, called upon me, and proposed to me to walk with him to the hill, upon which my father held his last interview with Jonathan Sewall in 1774 immediately before the commencement of the revolutionary War—as related by my father in the preface to the republication of the essays of Novanglus and Massachusettensis— I went accordingly with him upon the hill, which presents one of the most beautiful prospects, that I ever beheld an extensive view of islands; mountains, vallies, and the distant ocean with that own poor house, bosom’d high in tufted trees— Mr Daveis pointed out to me the spot where he supposed the interview between my father and Jonathan Sewall had been held— The place is now a grave-yard, and a deeply affecting spot for the monuments which it contains over the graves of Lieutenant Commandant Willian Burrows commander of the United State Brig Enterprize, and Samuel Blythe commander of the British Brig Boxer, captured by the Enterprize on the 5th. of September 1813. and brought into Portland— The Commanders of both vessels were killed in the action, and here they sleep in death, and in glory side by side, as if they had been man and wife— Mr Daveis said that he felt some mortification in stating that the monument over the remains of Lieutenant Burrows was erected at the expense, not of the citizens of Portland, collective or individual, but of Matthew L. Davis of New-York. Another Monument, which awakened long slumbering sensibilities in my breast was that of Commodore Preble, one of our gallant naval commanders, whose name carries with it round the world the honour of our Country— On returning with Mr Daveis to the Hotel, we met in the Street the Mayor of the City, Mr Ilsley, in former times Collector of the Customs and GenlWingate heretofore a Member of the House of Representatives, U.S. and whose wife is a daughter of the late General Henry Dearborn— With them there was a throng of Citizens of the place whom the Mayor stated to be desirous of paying their respects to me and of shaking hands with me, which they did for about half an hour in a hall of the Hotel. We then went to a new yet unfinished Courthouse and Exchange building, with a dome on the top of it, which we ascended and there again beheld the fair city at our feet, and the exquisitely beautiful prospects of hills, around and the more distant view of the Ocean— Met judge Ware, in his chamber adjoining the Court room and Mrs Ware was with him. The throng continued to shake hands, and I gave them a short parting address of half an hour in the Court room— At 12. Met General Wingate, Mrs Wingate and numerous Ladies at his house— Mrs Bailey (Charlotte Welsh) Short parting address— Dined at the Hotel— Stage to Portsmouth at 1:30. Rockingham house at 8.

At Portland yesterday Genl. Wingate had expressly invited me to his house at 12 O’Clock to meet the Ladies, who wished to see me— There were many there; but none with whom I had any previous acquaintance, except Mrs Wingate and Mrs Bailey— Many fine women, but whose very names escape me— My parting address to them was extremely Laconic—on our way back to the Hotel, we met three young Ladies who were going to Genl. Wingate’s, and whom Mr Daveis introduced to me in the Street— At his request we stop’d at one house, where he introduced to me two others— On our return to the Hotel, I received a polite note from Mr Albert Smith inviting me to dine with him at his boarding house— And while we were at dinner at the Hotel he came in, and I thanked him for his kindness and apologized for being deprived of the pleasure of accepting his invitation to dinner by our immediate departure for Portsmouth— In the Stage from Portland we had a very handsome young woman from Newburyport married at Portland, who was going to Newburyport; with a young man, perhaps her brother. Before reaching Saco, they left the Stage to proceed in a horse and Chaise. At Scarborough, the Innkeeper made himself known to me, as heretofore a Sea-Captain, introduced to me as Master of one of Mr Gray’s merchant vessels at St. Petersburg— His name is Hovey.— But since 1811. I had thoroughly forgotten him— From Portland to Portsmouth is 50 Miles— We passed through Saco, and over the river—then through Biddeford, Kennebunk, Wells, York Kittery, in view of the Boon Island light, and across the long bridge over the Piscataway river to Portsmouth; we came to the Rockingham house, where we found Mr Curtis’s son’s wife, with her daughter and son—and a MissThe town was in an uproar of Politics.— Mr Henry Hubbard a Senator in Congress from New-Hampshire was haranguing a loco foco convocation in one house and there was a crowded assemblage of whigs at another. The latter followed us, mob fashion, shouting, huzzaing, and calling me out by name— I went out to them, and as it was as dark as pitch, thanked them heartily for their kind reception—gave them good news from Maine, and asked them to excuse me from addressing them then whereupon they dispersed with three cheers— Mr and Mrs Austin called to see Mr Curtis— Mr Upham called upon me and apologized for the disturbance of our repose, by the tumultuous but friendly impetuosity of the people, which we cheerfully overlooked. He and several other gentlemen, urged me with great earnestness and pertinacity to stay at Portsmouth and address the whigs, and counteract the eloquence of Mr Hubbard— But we had irrevocably fixed to take the Stage this morning, and to close our excursion this day. We accordingly breakfasted at 6. A.M. and after a fruitless chase in the rain for a barber, We started in the Stage from the Rockingham house 16 Miles to Exter—then two Miles further to the place to which the railway from Boston to Portland has hitherto extended—there took the cars—landed at the Tremont house Boston at 1/2 past 12. and there parted from Mr Curtis who returned home to Roxbury— Found a Barber— Visit to Mr Abbott Lawrence who told me he had this day resigned his seat in Congress— Dined at the Tremont house. A Belknap—Chevalier Hulseman—Judge Smith of Florida—Captain Webster— We came in Gilletts Omnibus to Quincy— Arrived at Sunset— Family all well [symbols] Elizabeth De Wint here— Her Mother went to Boston Yesterday.

Clear morning— I went to the corner of Charles’s house, and saw the Sun—just risen 5:44. Heard the Revd. John Langdon Sibley, this morning, from 1. Corinthians 1.12. “Now this I say, that every one of you saith, I am of Paul: and I of Apollos; and I of Cephas, and I of Christ. 13. Is Christ divided? Was Paul crucified for you? or were ye baptized in the name of Paul?” This was a discourse on the diversities of Sentiment and opinions among men, as resulting from the constitution of human nature; and upon the duty of mutual toleration and liberality resulting therefrom— Mr Sibley’s remarks were sensible and judicious, manifesting a Christian temper and benevolent disposition; but not much depth—of observation or of research.— His delivery is good, but not remarkable— Much superior to any thing that I have heard the last two Sundays, since I left home. Mr Sibley was a Classmate of my son Charles at Cambridge— He dined with us— He expressed great curiosity to have mount Wollaston, and the place where John Hancock was born pointed out to him; which I did—walking over the hill to Meeting, after dinner— I had shewed him also at his request, my Library—the Volumes of my diary, and some of my Letter-books and my father’s . The original Letter to Nathan Webb of October 1755. and the Book copy of the Letter to my mother of 3. July 1776.—I gave him also copies of my three Eulogies, of the Oration of 4. July 1837 at Newbury-port—the Speech on the right of Petition in June 1838. The Jubilee of the Constitution, at New-York April 1839. and the Speech of May 1840. on the English system of smuggling.— Mr Sibley’s afternoon text was from 2. Corinthians—6:14—[“]for what fellowship hath righteousness with unrighteousness.”— I had not time in the leisure of this day, even to read through all the Letters which have been received here for me, during my absence; among which are invitations of 1. September from the Whigs of Michigan to attend and take part in a whig convention at Detroit on the 30th of September, from the whigs of North-Carolina to attend their Convention at Raleigh, on the 5th. of October, and from the whigs of the Western part of New-York to attend and address a Convention at Buffalo on the 7th. of October— Letters also from E. J. Lee of Alexandria, from Philip R. Fendall and from a Committee of the Proprietors of the second Presbyterian church at Washington, upon various political topics and religious concerns which will require my particular notice, and early attention— Mary-Louisa, my Granddaughter read to me in the French Bible, the third chapter of the Book of Judges, to which she had read before I went away.— Charles and his wife, the Midshipman John Quincy and Elizabeth C. Adams spent the Evening here— I have been several Nights in my sleepless hours brooding over a project of verses upon the memory of childhood.

My son went to Boston this morning, and returned home to dine— His wife, and Mary, went also to Boston, and took Elizabeth De Windt with them— She had received a Letter from her mother, who had left her here last Friday, and gone herself into Boston to Mrs Keating’s, and now directed Elizabeth to come to her— I went up the hill to Charles’s house it being the equinoctial day, but the Sun rose beclouded—and I could not note the time or place— With the exception of a short visit to my garden, nursery, orchard and seminary, the day was occupied with this diary, in which I have a new arrear of eight days to redeem— About Sunset, I walked to Mrs T. B. Adams’s, and found her recovered from a recent indisposition— Her Sister Mrs Foster is to leave her to-morrow, going on a visit to Bangor— The Midshipman John Quincy walked home with me, with the illumination of a splendid Aurora Borealis— With this sets in the sharp autumnal cold, which kindled a fire in our dining room; and I found one at Mrs T. B. Adams’s— At home I found Mr Price Greenleaf as a visitor, and my Son had a proof print of the portrait of my mother to be published with the volume of her Letters which he has prepared for publication, and which he expected would have been published before our departure for Nova-Scotia. The print is a copper plate engraving, from the Portrait in water Colours taken about 1764 or 1765 shortly after my mothers marriage—during her absence in England, about 1785. this portrait with that of my father taken at the same time were removed from the house at the foot of Penn’s hill, by my aunt Cranch to her house, where they remained upwards of 50 years, till about the this time last year, when I took my father’s portrait to lend to Mr Bancroft at Boston, to be engraved for a forth coming volume of his history of the United States— Since then, Charles has undertaken to publish this small volume of my mother’s Letters, and had this portrait engraved, to front the title-page. But it is wretchedly executed, and he doubts whether to accept and use it, or to publish the book without any portrait. I thought, bad as it is, that it is better than none—and better than to delay the publication till another plate can be engraved— The inconvenience of this would be increased by the fact, that there is already a favourable review of the Book in the North-American Review for the present quarter, which will be published the first of next Month— And so think the Ladies of the family.

And now that I shall at least for some time have no memorable daily facts to record, I ought from day to day to make up a summary of reflections resulting from my observations in a three weeks excursion to the British Provinces of Nova-Scotia, and New-Brunswick, and through the State of Maine, and a corner of New-Hampshire— For, to what purpose is travel, but to replenish the mind with observation? and to what purpose is a mind full of observation, but to impart?— Oh! for the mind of a Humboldt!— How poor and barren is mine!

Birth day of my Son Charles’s eldest Son, John Quincy who is seven years old— Cloudy morning, so that I could not observe the rising of the Sun— Miss Abigail Quincy with Miss Phelps and Mr Josiah Quincy junr two younger children Samuel and Mary paid a morning visit to our Ladies— My wife and Mrs John Adams, went this afternoon over to Weymouth— I planted the stone of a very large peach, with two Nova-Scotia plum-stones 6. Shagbark walnuts in the drupe, and 6 English white-oak acorns in patch 3 row 7 of the seminary, opposite the old plum tree— I had a large young Peach-tree, transplanted into this patch last autumn; which being now dead, I had taken out of the ground, and these Stones, nuts and acorns put down in its place— There is a black currant-bush, and an Apple-seedling growing in the Georgiana patch, where the violet blossomed through the whole of last Summer, and is not yet extirpated. I cannot approach the place but with sweet and bitter tears— I paid a visit to Mr Thomas Greenleaf of the early part of this Evening— Charles and his wife were here the latter part of it— We had fire in the dining room, and I had need of some self-controul to abstain from having one made in my Library where I was writing to retrieve these arrears— In our recent excursion the observation frequently recurred to me of the results upon the physical, political and moral face of the country, under the colonial, and the independent condition, compared with each other— The aspect of the Provinces of Nova-Scotia and New-Brunswick constantly reminded me of that of Massachusetts-Bay, in the days of my childhood, as far back as I can remember. The Provinces are prosperous—their population increases from year to year— The British Government, taught by woful experience the absurdity of expecting to raise revenue from these Colonies, passed to the other extreme, and pours forth from her own funds, with a lavish hand— They maintain their authority over the Provinces at enormous sacrifices of men and money. The Salaries of the Lieutenant Governors of Nova-Scotia and New-Brunswick, fall little short of that of the President of the United States. An army of 16000 men, is now maintained in these two Provinces and the Canada’s. The whole army of the United States is now 12500. Nearly doubled as it has been within the last 3 years— There are three regiments, the 8th. 23d. and 37th. stationed at Halifax besides divisions of Royal Artillery and Engineers— Twenty-three regiments of Nova-Scotia-Militia, all armed, officered and trained—a Navy of 26 armed vessels and 6 armed Steamers—all together presenting the aspect of a community clad in complete steel and prepared for defence against the most formidable assaults— There is a regiment the 69th. at St. John, and a Regiment the 36th. at Fredericton— In the Canadas are many more; and a Governor General, holding a Court, and maintaining an Establishment little less than royall. All this for a population less than one half equal to that of the State of New-York—and all this maintained at the expense of the British Nation— These possessions are cherished as destined to hold in check, and under controul the growing power of the United States of America, an object for which John Bull considers no sacrifice too great.
Sun rose 5:47. behind a lofty distant tree— Fahrenheit 38.

Morning visit from the Chevalier Hulsemann, Secretary of the Austrian legation; whom we met in the Steamer Bangor to Portland, and on our return to Boston at the Tremont house. I did not then recollect his name, having seen him not more than once or twice at Washington last winter— He told me that he had been out here with Mr Caleb Cushing at the Pic Nic on the 3d. and they had visited our family—but the Ladies had not remembered him any better than I did, and until this day knew not who he was— Mr Beale and his daughter Caroline were here this Evening; and Charles and his wife of course.— I walked this afternoon to Mr John Greenleaf’s, and saw him and his two daughters, Mrs Lucy and Mrs Mary Dawes. He is 78 years of age, of which he has been upwards of 60 years blind, and for some years past hard of hearing, though not absolutely deaf.— Mrs Greenleaf, my Cousin, once Lucy Cranch, is but three months younger than myself. She is now confined to her chamber, by a dropsical disease, from which there is no hopes of her recovery— I called next at the house of Mrs T. B. Adams, but she was gone with her son John Quincy, to visit Mr John Marston at Taunton, and Elizabeth was at Mr Edward Miller’s. My last visit was Dr Woodward who is building a house— There I met two young women daughters of Henry Wood— His wife is a daughter of Deacon Ebenezer Adams, first cousin both by father and mother’s side to my father. I did not know them. There is hardly an old family in this town, with whom I have not some affinity in blood— But to return to the province of Nova-Scotia— Mr Curtis purchased for me at Fredericton, Thomas C. Haliburtons Historical and Statistical account of Nova-Scotia, in two 8vo. Volumes, published in 1829. a very valuable work.— From this it appears that the population of the Provinces in 1790 was about 30000. in 1817. 82053. and in 1827. 123,848—besides 30000 in the Island of Cape Breton: Hence within the last half century the population has more than quadrupled; and has kept a full proportion to the average increase throughout the United States; though in no wise comparable to the increase in our Western States, or New-York or Pennsylvania— Two thirds of this population of Nova-Scotia proper consists of the remnants and descendants of 20000 loyalists or refugees from the North-American States who settled there in 1783 immediately after the close of the American revolutionary War— The numbers of the people now including the Island of Cape-Breton must exceed 200,000— The territory of the Peninsula covers an Area of 15617 square miles nearly double that of the State of Massachusetts; and with a population of 100 to a square mile, which is about that of Massachusetts, would number more than one million and a half of inhabitants— It is not probable that it will ever feed such numbers— Its situation however is favourable to commerce, and its climate to the establishment of manufactures. Of these there are now none, the policy of the mother country being to furnish them for the Province— They are imported duty free, and there is neither capital nor shill in the colony to start or maintain a competition with the manufacturers at home.

The day of the monthly meeting of the Massachusetts Historical Society, which I did purpose to attend; but on reflection, I thought it would be a useless waste of time, and concluded to stay at home. Since my excursion of three weeks, I find propensities of dissipation stealing upon me which it is advisable to controul, and to return as far as possible to the duties before me— Returning home last Evening, I met Mr Richards of the Quincy Lyceum who had called at my house, to solicit a Lecture from me for that Institution, which I promised to deliver before my departure for Washington— As yet the arrears of the Diary absorb all my time, excepting a morning hour, which I have devoted on resuming the perusal of Bancroft’s history of the United States— Elizabeth C. Adams dined and spent the evening with us— Charles attended a Meeting of the democratic party this Evening, at which George Bancroft, Collector of the Customs at Boston, Superintendant of Light-houses within the Commonwealth, and Commissioner for building a Custom house at Boston, delivered an electioneering democratic address— This practice of itinerant speech-making has suddenly broken forth in this Country to a fearful extent.— Electioneering for the Presidency, has spread its contagion to the President himself—to his now only competitor; to his immediate Predecessor—to one at least of his Cabinet Counsellors, the Secretary of War—to the Ex-candidates Henry Clay, and Daniel Webster, and to many of the most distinguished members of both Houses of Congress— Immense assemblages of the People are held—of 20, 30, 50,000 souls, where the first Orators of the Nation, address the multitude, not one in ten of whom can hear them, on the most exciting topics of the day— As yet the parties call and hold these meeting separately and seldom interfere with each other— But at the Baltimore convention last May one of the Marshals of the procession, a respectable mechanic of the city was killed, by an attempt of individuals of the opposite party to break it up— At a meeting a few days since on long Island, Mr Webster in a speech of two hours and a half, observed that there was to be held a meeting of the opposite party another great meeting at the same place on the next day; and he gave what was equivalent to a challenge to Silas Wright and all the administration leaders to meet him on the stump.— A hand bill was this day circulated in this town, severely reflecting on Mr Bancroft, for coming to deliver this address— Charles says that at Medford there has already been hostile collision between the parties—and the tendency of all this undoubtedly is, to the corruption of the popular elections, both by violence and fraud— Charles came in after hearing Mr Bancroft’s address, which was delivered at the Universalist Meeting house— Bancroft is an apostate federalist, as are almost to a man the leaders of the mock democracy of this State— Most of them, have cast off their caterpillar skin within the last five years— My father used to say of such
