Morning visit from Mr Thomas Greenleaf, my neighbour, and Mr Thomas Payson of Peterborough, New Hampshire, Classmates at Harvard University, and graduates of 1784. I have been for a few years past in occasional correspondence with Mr Payson, who at the age of 76 after a life not prosperous in the smiles of Fortune, retains great vivacity and sprightliness. He laughs as heartily as if he were but 25— Mrs De Windt and Harriet Welsh came out from Boston to spend the night here. Charles went to Boston, and returned to dine. He and his wife spent the Evening here— I gave an hour in the seminary, and planted English white oak acorns, and shagbark walnuts, with a peach and a plum stone, in patch 3. row 4. and patch 4 row 5. Walking up the hill to see the Sunset I met Mr Josiah Brigham at my Son’s house.— Settled Mr Curtis’s account of our expenses on our recent tour— Among my remarks during that excursion, was the contrast between the excessive election excitement, which we left behind us at Boston, and found again blazing out, on the very day of our entrance into the State of Maine, and the calm and almost lethargic condition of the British Provinces. The British Government makes itself felt there only by its favours— Levies no taxes; pays nearly all the charges of Government—keeps an army at great cost, and a considerable naval force, for the protection and defence of the Country; and humours the people in every thing— They have also made excellent roads through the forests of Nova-Scotia; and are now doing the same in New-Brunswick— No Government upon earth probably so assiduously labours to make itself acceptable to the people under its rule as these Colonial authorities— There are however representative assemblies in both Provinces, and in each a Legislative and an Executive Council— Their provincial Parliaments were like the House of Commons at home elected for seven years; but that of Nova-Scotia, is already reduced to four, and they are expecting the same alteration in New Brunswick— There is in Nova-Scotia, however, a sharp and sturdy opposition in the house of Assembly, and that body last year passed a vote of censure upon Sir Colin Campbell, the king’s Governor.— The British privy Council, fully approved the measures, censured by the Assembly; but they recalled Sir Colin, and since we were there Lord Falkland has arrived in the Steamer Britannia, at Halifax, and has taken his place— This is a very convenient mode of adjusting dissensions between the Legislative and Executive authorities— An election for a new house of assembly is now about to take and the prospect was of a large majority to sustain the last house, and against the Governor.— Lord Falkland will find no difficulty in disarming this majority; if he walks in the footsteps of Sir John Harvey— His qualification for the office is that his wife is a cousin of Queen Victoria; being a daughter of Mrs Jordan, and of the Sailor king, when duke of Clarence.

My daily task is the diary of the preceding day, and the redemption of one day of recent arrears— It failed of accomplishment this day, because I wasted my time in idle researches among newspaper advertisements— Mrs De Windt and Harriet Welsh, had intended to return this Morning to Boston, but finally concluded to stay and dine at my Son’s— I dined there with them, and Mr Beale and Mr Lunt— Immediately after dinner, my wife and Mrs John, and Mrs Charles, took Mrs De Windt and Miss Welsh into Boston left them at Mrs. Allyne Otis’s and returned home this evening.— Charles was not here— Mrs De Windt had with her the first copy of the volume of my mother’s Letters. It deserves notice how very little intercourse there has heretofore been between the People of the United States and those of the adjoining British Provinces, and most especially with Nova-Scotia— Yet they well deserve to be studied by a young American Statesman; for they are destined to have hereafter a very powerful influence over the condition of the North American Union and especially over its Northern and Western Sections. The Policy of the British Government has been to excite and main divisions of interest among the colonies themselves as well as to nourish and stimulate their animosities against the neighbouring States. In 1784. the Province of New-Brunswick was set off from Nova-Scotia, and constituted a separate colony— So was the island of Cape-Breton, which has however been since re-annexed to Nova-Scotia. There are very perceptible mutual rivalries and jealousies between the Provinces and, a great indifference in both to the Canada’s.— They levy an impost duty of five percent upon all imported goods from one to the other, and it is very apparently part of the political system at home to keep them as much as possible alienated from each other; that all my be more perfectly dependent upon the common parent— Another precaution at home is a rigorous prohibition to recruit any of the regiments in the provinces— Of the ten companies constituting a regiment they always retain four in England in depot; and send them out from time to time, to supply the vacancies by death or desertion. The last are very rare— The men are enlisted for life, and as they are all taken from the paupers of the three kingdoms, and are fed, clad and lodged at the king’s expense, and trained exclusively to the performance of military service, they are nested in a condition of existence from which they have little temptation to depart, especially at the risk of capture and severe punishment— Yet on the day that we were at Saint John, a Court martial was held upon a Soldier who had deserted from the 69th. regiment, and who one of the Officers said had been taken at Portland— I mentioned this at Portland, to their great surprize—

Mr Motte is the Pastor of a small congregational Church in Boston.— He is a native of South-Carolina, and was a Classmate, and two years chum of my dear Son George at Harvard University— He was educated and ministered sometime in South-Carolina, as an episcopal clergyman, but upon consciencious conviction became a convert to the unitarian doctrine, and was for sometime settled as Minister of the Unitarian church, at Washington— For the last ten years he has been Minister of the South Congregation, Washington Street Boston— He preached this day at our Church, by exchange with Mr Lunt— His morning text was from James 5:11. [“]Behold we count them happy, which endure. Ye have heard of the patience of Job, and have seen the end of the Lord; that the Lord is very pitiful, and of tender mercy.” and he read part of the first, and of the last chapters of Job— Patience under affliction was the exhortation of his discourse, and I thought he had selected this Sermon for delivery here, with reference to my misfortunes, and to his former relations with my beloved Son— I felt grateful to him for his intention— He dined with us. But the conversation which seemed most agreeable to him, was upon European politics. His afternoon text was John 20.31. [“]But these are written, that ye might believe that Jesus is the Christ, the Son of God; and that believing ye might have life through his name.”— Upon the evidences of Christianity. My attention and thoughts were too much absorbed by the volume of my Mothers Letters which my Son has published, and of which he sent me this morning a copy— An admirable Memoir of her life, written by him is prefixed to the Letters, and the reading of it affected me till the tears streamed down my face— It disabled me for all other occupation, and the arrears of this diary, and the Sermon of Barrow were forgotten Charles was here this Evening; but his wife was detained at home by the rain which fell copiously. I had heard Mary Louisa read two chapters of the Book of Judges in Saci’s french Bible, and had read the 6th. chapter of the first Volume of Bancroft’s History of the United States— This chapter is entitled restrictions on Colonial Commerce— It is a very lame account of the English Navigation Act, and a florid panegyric upon the first settlers of Virginia; upon the soil, and climate of that Country—upon the Indian Monarchs, Powhatan and Opechancanough in equal measure. Bancroft is that combination of sycophant and slanderer, which formed Shakespears Iago— The “flatteur dehonté, et calomniateur au besoin” of Mirabeau. With all this he has transcendent talents and indefatigable industry— Every page of his history teems with evidences of profound research, quick perception and brilliant imagination— It is extremely entertaining— The style diffuse and declamatory; far less chaste, though more fascinating than that of Irving or of Prescott. The morality ostentatious, but very defective.

Morning visit from a Mr Smith with a young girl his Sister. He is a brother of Mr Isaac T. Smith, who came to me on the first of this Month on board of the Steamer Acadia, with a repeated application to me to deliver a Lecture next November before the New-York Lyceum— I answered again indecisively but discouragingly and promised an answer definitive at an early day. In the afternoon I had a visit from Mr James L. Curry late President of the Boston Mechanic Apprentices library Association, with his Successor the present President of the same Society, requesting me to deliver the introductory Lecture, about the first of November to their Winters course— Mr Webster had encouraged them to expect that he would perform this service for them— But he is now itinerant as a political orator, and has informed them that his engagements will not admit of his being here in time to discourse as he had promised them. These perpetual, and almost numberless applications are to me very distressing: between the wish and the inability to comply with the request of a favour, itself importing kindness and respect— I have however declined, upon the chance that I may be called to Washington, before the close of the next Month— Mr Curry has ceased to be President of the Mechanic Apprentice’s library Association, because his apprenticeship has terminated. Mr Haley was the Secretary when I prepared the two Lectures for them, and delivered one of them last November— I this day brought up the arrears of diary into which it fell during my recent excursion, but leave many remarks which I ought to have made, never to be recorded.— In the account of the visit that I made to Sampson Salter Blowers, at Halifax I was mistaken in the statement that he had been the prosecutor of Captain Preston, and the Soldiers of the 29th. Regiment, for the Tragedy of the 5th. of March 1770— He was on the contrary one of the Counsel for the accused, with my father and Josiah Quincy. The Prosecutors were Samuel Quincy, and Robert Treat Paine— Blowers however named as one of the Counsel for the Soldiers, appears to have taken no part in the argument— There were five indictments, one for each of the five inhabitants killed in the fray, each charging first the soldier, whose fire killed the individual charged in the Bill as murdered, and then charging Captain Preston and other soldiers of the guard as accomplices in the murder— The first indictment against Wemms charged also four individuals not soldiers as accomplices in the crime; they were however separately tried, not till the next December, and were all acquitted—on the five indictments, Preston, and six of the eight Soldiers were acquitted— Two Matthew Killroy, and Hugh Montgomery, were found not guilty of murder, but guilty of Manslaughter, and were discharged upon the claim of the benefit of clergy and the brand of cold iron upon the hand— There is more curious matter in this trial which would make a good Lecture— Midshipman John Quincy was here this Evening.

There is no waste of time like that of reading. My mother’s Letters. Bancroft’s history— Speeches, and pamphlets—and above all newspapers; which steal the hours away and leave nothing for memory to record— Having redeemed my last arrears, I expected to have this day several hours of leisure; but could accomplish nothing more, than the record of yesterday, and an answer to John H. Weedon and sundry others, Committee of a whig Tippecanoe association of Pawtucket, Rhode-Island, from whom I have an invitation to appoint some day, to go and address them upon the Presidential Election— I declined— Afternoon visit from Dr Palfrey; and Mr Lothrop, the Minister of the Brattle Street Church and Society. Dr Palfrey’s object was to repeat the solicitation to me to furnish two Articles for the North American Review—of which he is now the Editor and Proprietor— One a biographical account of William Tudor junr. and the other an Article upon the present condition of the Empire and trade of China; and particularly upon the case or prospect of War between Great-Britain, and the celestial Empire— It is impossible for me to prepare an Article upon either of these subjects because I have not, and have never been able to obtain the material facts of the life of Mr Tudor—and because I have no particular information; nothing but loose, disconnected, Newspaper Reports upon the controversy between Great-Britain and China— I received a few days since from Mr John M Forbes, a folio volume of 458 pages, being the Correspondence relating to China, laid before both Houses of the British Parliament, last Spring by command of Queen Victoria— With the aid of this volume together with the information which I might collect from other sources, which it will indicate, I might make out a tolerable Article, but for the want of time. As it is, I shall have more than enough to do, to prepare a Lecture for the Quincy Lyceum, which I have promised, and the subject of which is yet floating in uncertainty upon my mind— In addition to all my other troubles, I took last Saturday, I know not how, a severe cold, and catarrhal cough, which torments me ever since. Visited my garden and nursery this afternoon— Gathered sundry Shagbarks and English white oak Acorns. Two rows of which, 6 of each in each row, I planted—at the left hand of the garden gate next North of the House— I have numerous fruit and forest trees of growth from one to ten years old—but twenty years are necessary to raise an orchard, and thirty years for a forest so that I might leave the accomplishment of that purpose to my Successors— At the dusk of Evening, I walked to Mrs T. B. Adams’s to deliver a Letter to her daughter Elizabeth which I had received this morning— But Mrs Adams, and Elizabeth, and John Quincy were all gone to Medford, and are expected to return to-morrow Evening— Dr Palfrey spoke to me this afternoon of an Article in the National Intelligencer; upon Featherstonhaugh’s report on the North-eastern boundary, with a map, which I have not seen—

Deacon Spear was here this morning, and I had much conversation with him concerning my property in this town, and the necessary measures for the prudent and economical management of it; a subject exceedingly irksome to me, and for which I become from day to day more and more incompetent— The Mount Wollaston farm, the Penn’s hill farm—the Mansion house farm, the Salt-marsh and the woodlands, the repairs and preservation of buildings, the making and maintenance of fences, and the continual laying out of roads, all require persevering care, and skillful attention, nearly all of which I have committed in trust to my Son, but of which a small portion remains sufficient to be burdensome upon my spirits, and to tax my time— I agreed to go into the woods some day next week with Deacon Spear, and Mr Lemuel Humphreys the Weymouth surveyor in search of a woodlot of which I am part proprietor, but how much, and with whom as tenant in common I know not— I am and for many years have been taxed for the whole; and as the wood upon it is now in condition to be cut off and sold, I propose to exercise that right of possession for the whole, responsible to each of the other proprietors for his part of the proceeds— Lewis Bass was next here, collector of the town and County tax. 288 dollars which I paid by a check on the Quincy Stone bank— Bass and Harvey Field are joint Lessees of my Penn’s hill farm— The lease expires next April and Field and Bass are desirous of having a new lease each for himself of the whole. I told Bass that I should prefer to have him sole tenant for the whole, but referred him for final arrangements to my Son.— He and his wife, and three elder children dined with us, and about an hour before dinner Mrs De Windt came in from Boston with a young Clergyman named Simmons, who has acquired some notoriety by preaching two Sermons at Mobile in the State of Alabama, where he had been two years settled, exhorting his hearers to emancipate their Slaves— This was no longer ago than last May; and the immediate consequence was that he was exhorted to depart from the City and the State, which he did, without delay. Since then he has been some time preaching at Fishkill landing, and became an inmate in the family of Mrs De Wint. They dined with us, and returned this Evening to Boston— After dinner I took him with me into my garden, Nursery and Seminary to view my seedling trees; and then up the hill to the porch of Charles’s house to view the prospect of Boston Bay and City, Mount Wollaston, and the villages of Quincy.— While we were at dinner, Mr Barnard, brother of the one who came on the 31st. of August with Dr Bowditch came for an answer whether I would deliver a Lecture before the Warren Street Association— I promised an answer within ten days.
